Detailed Description

A special container for chunks of memory.

The flm_Buffer class is a simple container for memory chunks, it holds the content of this chunk, its length, and a handler to free it. This handler will be called when the reference counter of the buffer reaches zero. For example, if you allocated a buffer using malloc() the free handler will be the free() function.

Definition in file buffer.h.

Typedef Documentation

typedef void(* flm_BufferFreeContentHandler)(void *ptr)

A pointer to simple 'free' handler, the libc's free() function can be used directly if the content of the buffer was created with malloc().

Definition at line 48 of file buffer.h.

Function Documentation

flm_Buffer* flm_BufferNew ( char *  content,
size_t  length,
flm_BufferFreeContentHandler  fr_handler 
)

Create a new buffer from an existing chunk of memory.

Parameters:
contentA pointer to any array of characters.
lengthThe lenght (in bytes) of this array.
fr_handlerA pointer to a desallocation function.
Returns:
A pointer to a new flm_Buffer object.
Example with static string:
 flm_Buffer * buffer;
 
 buffer = flm_BufferNew ("test", 5, NULL);
Example with dynamic string:
 flm_Buffer * buffer;
 char *       string;

 string = strdup ("test");
 buffer = flm_BufferNew (string, 5, free);
Examples:
Buffer unit tests.
flm_Buffer* flm_BufferPrintf ( const char *  format,
  ... 
)

Create a new flm_Buffer object and fill it with a formatted string.

This function is the equivalent of printf() for buffers. Internally, it uses the vsnprintf() function so all the formatting rules are the same.

Remarks:
You should never use an user input as format string, see the BUGS section of the printf() manual page.
Parameters:
formatA printf()-style format string.
Returns:
A pointer to a new flm_Buffer object.
Example:
  flm_Buffer * buffer;

  buffer = flm_BufferPrintf ("TEST %d %s ", 42, "coucou");
  assert (strcmp (flm_BufferContent (buffer), "TEST 42 coucou ") == 0);
Examples:
Buffer unit tests.
size_t flm_BufferLength ( flm_Buffer *  buffer)

Returns the length (in bytes) of the buffer.

Remarks:
Note that buffers created with flm_BufferPrintf() do not count the ending \0 in the total length, even if this character is present at the end of the buffer content.
Parameters:
bufferA pointer to a flm_Buffer object.
Returns:
The length of the buffer in bytes.
Examples:
Buffer unit tests, and Monitor unit tests.
char* flm_BufferContent ( flm_Buffer *  buffer)

Returns the content of the buffer.

Remarks:
Note that buffers created with flm_BufferPrintf() will have an ending \0, even is this character is not included in the total length.
Parameters:
bufferA pointer to a flm_Buffer object.
Returns:
The content of the buffer.
Examples:
Buffer unit tests, and Monitor unit tests.
flm_Buffer* flm_BufferRetain ( flm_Buffer *  buffer)

Increment the reference counter.

Parameters:
bufferA pointer to a flm_Buffer object.
Returns:
The same pointer, this function cannot fail.
void flm_BufferRelease ( flm_Buffer *  buffer)

Decrement the reference counter.

When the counter reaches zero the 'free' handler will be called to free the memory consumed by the buffer content, then the buffer object itself will be freed.

Parameters:
bufferA pointer to flm_Buffer object..
Examples:
Buffer unit tests, and Monitor unit tests.
